title: What is Programming? (Teaching a Robot)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine you're teaching a robot to make a sandwich:

YOU (to robot): "Make me a sandwich"
ROBOT: *stares blankly*

Why? The robot doesn't understand English!

YOU (in robot language):
1. Open bread bag
2. Take out 2 slices
3. Open peanut butter jar
4. Spread on slice 1
5. Open jelly jar
6. Spread on slice 2
7. Put slices together

ROBOT: *makes perfect sandwich!*

That's PROGRAMMING:
• Computers are like robots - they don't understand human language
• You write INSTRUCTIONS in a language they understand (C#)
• Instructions must be PRECISE and IN ORDER
• Computer follows instructions EXACTLY

Think: Programming = Writing a detailed recipe that a computer can follow!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Console = the terminal/output window. WriteLine = write a line of text. The text goes in quotes. This is how you display messages to users!
Quotes mark the beginning and end of text (called a 'string'). Everything between quotes is displayed exactly as written.
Semicolon marks the end of an instruction. Like a period ends a sentence, semicolon ends a code statement. Forgetting it causes errors!
Two slashes start a comment. Everything after // on that line is ignored by computer. Use comments to explain what your code does!

challenge.instructions:
Write your first program!

1. Display "Hello, World!" (the traditional first program)
2. Display your name
3. Display your favorite hobby
4. Display a message about what you want to learn

Use Console.WriteLine() for each line.
Don't forget the semicolons!
Add comments explaining what each line does.
challenge.hint: Use Console.WriteLine() with text in quotes. End each line with semicolon. Add // comments to explain!
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting semicolons: Every statement needs a semicolon at the end! Without it, you get an error. Console.WriteLine("Hi"); ✓ Console.WriteLine("Hi") ✗
Missing quotes: Text must be in quotes! Console.WriteLine(Hello) ✗ Console.WriteLine("Hello") ✓
Case sensitivity: C# cares about CAPITAL vs lowercase! Console.WriteLine ✓ console.writeline ✗ Always match exactly!
Spelling: WriteLine not Writeline! Computer doesn't autocorrect spelling errors.
